utterances: That's true.
You don't get to do that unless you're Jack Nicholson.
OK.
All right.
Let's get down to puzzle business.
Remind me, what was last week's challenge?
Yes.
I said name two animals, both mammals, one of them domestic, the other wild.
I said put their letters together, and rearrange the result to name another mammal, this one wild and not seen naturally around North America.
What mammal is it?
Well, the domestic one is the dog.
The wild one is the gnu - G-N-U.
And you put those letters together, and you get the dugong - D-U-G-O-N-G.
Did you know a dugong?
No, no.
Well, it's a large plant-eating mammal off the coast of Australia sometimes called a sea cow related to the manatee.
Sea cow I know.
Yeah.
But a dugong.
There you go.
It's status is listed as threatened so it's a good thing to know about.
But save the dugong doesn't really, like, roll off the tongue for a bumper sticker, I suppose.
(Laughter) Well, maybe we can start something.
Yeah.
We could start something.
(Laughter).
OK, so this was a hard one.
Even so, we got 104 correct answers.
Our winner this week is Michael Kurh from Geneva, Illinois.
He joins us on the line now.
Hey, Michael, congratulations.
Thank you.
So you clearly knew what a dugong was.
Yes, I've been trying to get my babies to say that as their first word.
(Laughter) How old are your kids?
They're four and a half months old.
Twins, huh?
Congratulations.
What do you do in Geneva, Michael?
Right now, I'm getting ready to go back to school 'cause hopefully I will be a teacher someday.
Well, three men have been identified as being the bombers who struck in London last Thursday.
One of them's called Shahzad Tanweer.
He's 23, was born in Branston, lived all his life in the Beeston area of Leeds.
His father was born in Pakistan and owns a fish-and-chips shop.
And the second one was a 19-year-old.
His name's Hasib Hussain, and it was his disappearance on the day of the attacks which provided one of the vital clues which led police to Leeds.
He was reported missing by his mother at about 10:00 at night on Thursday.
The third man is called Mohammed Sadique Khan.
Now he comes from Dewsbury, a town outside Leeds.
He's a 30-year-old man of Pakistani origin.
He was married to a lady called Hasena(ph) and they had a baby girl approximately around eight months old.
And what about the fourth suspect?
Any word on him?
Well, all we know about the fourth suspect so far is that he also comes from the same area, from West Yorkshire, but in terms of a name and who he is so far, we don't know that information yet.
There are talk of three of these bombers being British-born and one of them is possibly not British-born.
Have you been able to speak to any of the families of these suspects?
Yes.
We've been speaking to the uncle of Shahzad Tanweer, the 23-year-old.

His uncle, Bashir Amed, told us about his nephew and said that he'd been religious for some time, but he'd never talked about paradise, that he thought he was going to London last Thursday for some religious event and they thought he'd been a victim in the terrorist attack.
Apparently all say he went to Pakistan for a period of time.
He'd also been to Afghanistan, but he thought that when he went to Pakistan, it was just to improve his reading of the Koran.
And he just says they're in total shock.
The family's in total shock.
And he said, `We've lost everything.'
How about these raids yesterday that police carried out?
They turned up some high-quality explosives.
Do you have more on that?
Well, they went to four--in fact, they had six raids altogether.
They went to four houses.
The first house was in an area of Leeds called Beeston, just a normal terrace, three floors with some conifers in front, window baskets.
It looks--totally ordinary house.
And then later on in the morning about 11:30 yesterday morning, police came to the area which I'm in now in Burley and they cordoned off a house here, carried out a controlled explosion.
This area here is where they think the bombs were made.

When you say this is an ordinary neighborhood, is it socially isolated from the rest of Leeds, or are people just leading completely ordinary lives here and it turns out there's a bomb factory next door?
Well, Leeds is a very multicultural city where Muslims and Hindus and British-born people all live together.
And so they're very surprised that the terrorists have come from their areas of Leeds.
I wonder if they aren't concerned, that is that maybe there's going to be some kind of backlash directed against their neighborhood.
They were very concerned about backlash.
They were very concerned that Muslims might be attacked.

There have been a number of attacks on mosques around Britain, already one in the neighboring city of Bradford and one in Leeds itself where just minor attacks, but there are fears that this could lead to more, especially now we know that these men who committed the crimes in London were suicide bombers.
The BBC's Mark Saxby speaking with us from Leeds.
Mark, thank you.
Thank you.
From NPR News, this is WEEKEND EDITION.
I'm Liane Hansen.
And joining us is puzzle master Will Shortz.
Will, how are you?
Hi, Liane.
Excellent.
How are you?
Very well, thank you.
The challenge last week - this is something that seemed easy, but it turned out to be a little bit harder than at least I thought it was.
Would you repeat it?
Yes.
I said name a famous American singer, one who's living, six letters in the first name, six letters in the last.
I said write it out from left to right.
Cross out six consecutive letters from inside the name, leaving the start and end intact, and the result will be the six-letter last name of a U.S.
president.
Who is it?

You know, I wonder whether folks did it from listing the presidents' names and then try to find singers around it, or trying to start with the singers, because there are so many genres, you never know where you're going to go.
What was the answer?
The answer is Willie Nelson, and remove those middle letters, you get Wilson, as in Woodrow Wilson.
Well, we had over 1,900 entries from people who tried to solve the puzzle, and our randomly selected winner is Chris Roberts.
He joins us from Richmond, Virginia.
Hi, Chris.
Hello.
First of all, how did you solve the puzzle?
By getting Wilson and moving backwards.
There you go.
What do you do in Richmond?
I'm a counter man at a coffee shop, Captain Buzzy's Beanery, which is located in a historic section of Richmond known as Church Hill.
How long have you been playing the puzzle?
I met a wonderful woman three years ago this month named Diane, who introduced me to the puzzle.
Diane and her daughter Rachel have been playing for years, but I've only been doing it for three years.
But you were courageous enough to actually send in an answer.
Yes.
All right.
Well, you know what happens now.
Yes.
Are you ready?
I am ready.
